name.text: 12.1.4.1 The normal line to a curve

questiontext.text:
The normal line to a curve

We have already noted that, at any point \((x_0, y_0)\) on a curve \(y = f(x)\) (so that \(y_0=f(x_0)\)), the tangent and normal lines are perpendicular. Thus if the equations of the tangent and normal lines are respectively:

\[\qquad y = mx + c \qquad \textrm{and} \qquad y = nx + d, \]

then recalling that two lines are perpendicular if the product of theirs slopes is \(-1\) we can see that \(m = -\dfrac{1}{ n}\) or, equivalently \(n = - \dfrac{1}{ m}\). 

We have also noted that slope of the tangent line can be calculated from the derivative, i.e.,

\[ m =  \dfrac{df}{dx}\bigg|_{x_0}.\]

Thus we can also obtain \(n\) from this information. To find \(d\), we use the fact that the point \((x_0, y_0)\) lies on the normal line \(y = nx + d\)  so \(n x_0 + d = f(x_0)\) leading to \(d = f(x_0) - nx_0\). Though it is better to work this out in each case rather than trying to recall this a formula. The takeaway should be that we can do this and how.
